## ndarray

* NumPyâ€™s array class is called `ndarray`
* all elements must be the same type

```{python, eval=TRUE}
import numpy as np
np.__version__
```

```{python, eval=TRUE}
# create an array from a regular Python list 
myarray = np.array([[ 1., 2., 3.],  
                    [ 4., 5., 6.]])
print(myarray)
```

*********************************************************************

## attributes

```{python, eval=TRUE}
myarray.ndim
myarray.shape
myarray.dtype
myarray.size
myarray.itemsize
myarray.data
```

*********************************************************************

## indexing

```{python, eval=TRUE}
# first row, first column
myarray[0,0]
myarray[1,1]
myarray[:2, 1:3]
```

*********************************************************************

## methods

```{python, eval=TRUE}
myarray.reshape((3,2))
myarray.ravel() 
# myarray.view() # shallow copy
# myarray.copy() # deep copy
```


`.ravel()`

## constructors

```{python, eval=TRUE}
np.empty((3,4))
np.zeros((3,4))
np.ones((3,4))
np.arange(12).reshape((3,4))
np.linspace(0, 1, 12).reshape((3,4)) 
```

Note the difference between np.ndarray and np.array() . The former is an actual data type, while the latter is a function to make arrays from other data structures
